properties.description: Cotton wants to be a perennial, but it’s forced by industrial agriculture to grow as an annual. More than 90% of cotton planted in the United States is a genetically modified (GM) variety engineered and patented by Monsanto Corporation. Because Monsanto owns the rights to this seed, it is illegal for farmers to save, reuse, or breed the seeds that result from their crops.
properties.title: Cotton Plant Life Cycle
Planting
properties.description: Aiken, South Carolina farmer Carl Brown and his farm assistant, Grover, plant more than 1,000 acres of genetically modified Bt (Bacillus thuringiensis) cotton in May 2008. Genetically modified cotton was introduced in 1998 and is now planted on thousands of farms every spring, accounting for approximately 93% of total cotton production in the United States in 2010.

properties.title: Weeds and Insects
properties.description: Genetically modified cotton seeds have reduced the need for heavy use of herbicides and pesticides, but have not eliminated it. Carl and Grover spray their fields with glyphosate just after planting to try to prevent chemically-resistant pig weed from taking over young cotton plants. Spraying for insects occurs throughout the summer but only when absolutely necessary because each field that requires spraying increases input costs of labor, fuel, and time.

properties.title: Water and Weather
properties.description: Always at the mercy of mother nature, Carl relies entirely on regular rainfall to irrigate his fields. By mid June, hot and dry weather has stunted some of his cotton, but rain arrives later in the growing season.

properties.title: Farm Labor
properties.description: Farming equipment can easily cost more than $350,000 per machine. To keep their business viable, Carl and Grover modify equipment in the farm's shop to undertake multiple tasks and prepare harvesting equipment for use in the months ahead.

properties.title: Global Financial Crisis
properties.address: Financial District, New York, NY, USA
properties.description: In the middle of the 2008 cotton growing season, input costs soar. Cotton commodity prices collapse from a high of 98 cents to a low of 39 cents per pound as markets around the world respond to the widening credit crisis and bank failures. Cotton demand falls worldwide as manufacturing declines, leaving farmers, gin operators, and merchants uncertain who will buy their cotton.

properties.title: Harvest
properties.description: Harvesting begins after the cotton plants drop their leaves. The southeastern climate forces most farmers to use chemicals to speed up the plants' defoliation so that it can be picked more cleanly by mechanized equipment. After picking, the cotton is dumped into modules, pressed and released, and then covered and left in the field.

properties.title: Cotton Ginning
properties.address: 301 Boyce Lawton Dr, Cameron, SC 29030, USA
properties.description: Truck drivers from Cameron Cotton and Seed Company pick up Carl's cotton from his fields in Aiken and transport it to the gin in Cameron, 70 miles away. The gin removes seeds and trash and presses the cotton into 500 pound bales. Each bale receives a PBI (permanent bale identification) bar code which pins it to Carl’s farm and to its sample, which is graded for quality. Seasonal workers from Texas perform much of the labor, working well into the night for two to three months. Far from their families and support systems, the work is long and difficult, yet the presence of seasonal workers in Cameron makes a significant impact on the local economy.

properties.title: Cotton Merchants
properties.description: The majority of Mr. Brown’s cotton is sold into a cooperative market which insulates him from the dramatic drop in commodity prices. The remainder of his cotton is purchased by a merchant, Mr. Jordan Lea, in Greenville, SC. Lea brokers the sale of cotton directly to mills or to other dealers in the US, China, and Pakistan. Once cotton leaves a farmer's hands it becomes part of a global exchange of cotton from points all over the world.

properties.title: Savannah Cotton Warehouse
properties.description: A truck is loaded with cotton in Cameron, SC and then heads southeast, to the Port of Savannah in Georgia. It passes through a nearby warehouse for temporary storage before it is staged and then loaded again onto a shipping container for its journey to an overseas buyer. At the warehouse in Savannah, shipping containers are unpacked, repacked, sealed, and eventually picked up by another truck that hauls the container to the port.

properties.title: Port of Savannah
properties.address: 2 Main St, Garden City, GA 31408, USA
properties.description: The Port of Savannah in Garden City, Georgia moves more than 2 million shipping containers a year. High above the port, workers sit in the cabs of cranes where they move standardized shipping boxes on and off container ships with efficiency and speed. Each shipping container has a unique number which is pinned to its contents and destination. The Georgia Ports Authority shipped over 52 billion dollars worth of goods in 2009, which represents 7.6% of US containerized trade in the United States.

properties.title: Yangshan Deep Water Port
properties.address: Tongxin 1st Rd, Shengsi, Zhoushan, Zhejiang, China
properties.description: Container ships carry cargo across the sea to China. On the ocean, with a horizon stretching endlessly in all directions, one could easily feel lost. But even here, cotton is being tracked: it has been weighed and rated, marked and traced. Even in its container it is surveilled, pinned to a specific geography at every moment. Cotton arrives into China through a number of sea ports, among them the Yangshan Deep Water Port, one of the largest container ports in the world.

properties.title: Wai Gao Qiao Free Trade Zone
properties.address: Siming Xinqu Rd, Fengxian, Shanghai, China
properties.description: A shipping container of cotton is inspected near the port and then transported to a free trade zone where it awaits its buyer. American cotton is stored in the FTZ alongside cotton from Brazil, India, and Pakistan. A Free Trade Zone is a politically defined region where raw materials and finished products are excused from taxes normally imposed by a country on imported and exported items. At the Wai Gao Qiao Free Trade Zone near Shanghai, workers load American and Indian cotton on a truck bound for the textile city of Changzhou, a city of 4.5 million people two hours from Shanghai. The cotton will be delivered to the mill that purchased it and processed into yarn.

properties.title: Raw Cotton Becomes Yarn
properties.description: At East Dye, a large yarn and weaving factory in Changzhou, workers oversee all aspects of the transformation of raw cotton into yarn and eventually textiles. A truckload of cotton from India arrives from the port and is unpacked for processing into a warehouse alongside cotton from China and Mississippi.

properties.title: Yarn Factory
properties.description: At the East Dye factory in Chanzhou, workers oversee the largely mechanized spinning process that turns raw cotton into yarn. Spindles of yarn are stacked together for dying, dried, and then cleaned and wrapped for distribution and sale. The dying and finishing of textiles creates a large environmental impact, requiring significant amounts of water, energy and chemicals. In countries without strong environmental protections or monitoring, the byproducts of conventional textile manufacturing are often released into the environment, leading to significant and negative health and environmental effects.

properties.title: Heddling
properties.address: Dongxin Rd, Wujin, Changzhou, Jiangsu, China
properties.description: Heddling captures the rhythm and movement of two textile workers at Shen You factory in Changzhou, China as they draw warp threads through the eyes of heddle needles. They sit across from one another all day while in the room next to them giant looms generate a din that signifies their perpetual labor.

properties.title: Weaving
properties.address: Dongxin Rd, Wujin, Changzhou, Jiangsu, China
properties.description: Workers in the large and deafening weaving rooms at the Shen You factory in Changzhou spend all day monitoring looms, fixing broken threads, and ensuring that each loom continues to function. In an adjacent room, workers inspect, repair and clean the newly woven fabrics, removing any marks left by the machines. The fabric is then ready for washing, and piles of fabric are hauled away by a worker from a "shadow factory" nearby. Shadow factories are smaller factories that help larger factories meet the strict production deadlines imposed by overseas buyers.

properties.title: Liu Chengfeng 刘成凤
properties.address: Dongxin Rd, Wujin, Changzhou, Jiangsu, China
properties.description: Liu Chengfeng 刘成凤, a nineteen year old worker at Shen You factory, explains how she came to be a migrant worker. Many young women leave rural provinces in China in search of a better life in factory cities. Liu Chengfeng is part of the largest migration of people in human history. The number of people living and working away from their homes in China is estimated to be 160 to 230 million people.

properties.title: Clothing Production
properties.description: Mrs. Jiang, owner of Yuan Tian Clothing Company, manages around 80 workers at her factory in Shanghai. She oversees all the production processes- from pattern making, sourcing of fabrics and clothing accessories, sewing, inspection, and packaging. Mrs. Jiang has completed orders for many US and European clothing brands and large US retailers.

properties.title: Hao Junmei 郝俊镁 and Liu Shizheng 刘施正
properties.description: Two workers in the sewing room of Yuan Tian factory, Liu Shizheng and Hao Junmei, talk about living far away from family and friends, overtime work, and how much they are paid for their piece work in the factory.

properties.title: Shanghai Farmers' Market
properties.address: Longchang Rd & Yangshupu Rd, Yangpu, Shanghai, China
properties.description: Every factory worker at Yuan Tian eats lunch and dinner at the factory. Cook Zhao Leiyou 赵耒友  shops every morning at the Yangpu District farmer’s market to buy meat and vegetables for the day’s meals. After moving through the market and making his purchases, Zhao Leiyou determined that the day’s menu would be sliced pork meat stir fried with lettuce root and salted eggs, stir fried pork liver, stir fried mi xian and eggplants and vegetable soup. And, of course, rice and mantou.

properties.title: Recycling Fabric Scraps
properties.description: Mrs. Jiang, the owner of Yuan Tian Clothing Company, sells left over fabric from clothing production to a recycler. Cotton and polyester scraps are recirculated in a different manufacturing economy, broken down into raw materials for new products.

properties.title: Cotton Products Factory
properties.address: Xiaoshao Rd, Xiaoshan, Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China
properties.description: In a factory in Hangzhou, workers assemble cotton and down quilts, blankets, and bedspreads for several popular US brands. A slogan in the courtyard of the factory complex reminds workers to "STRENGTHEN COMPETITIVE AWARENESS AND BUILD TEAM SPIRIT."

properties.title: Tan Mian Hua 弹棉花
properties.description: Tan mian hua is beating cotton, the traditional process of making a cotton quilt. The cotton inside the quilt is recycled every year by beating it until it is like new again. Tan mian hua workers in China used to wander the streets of cities and towns in the fall offering their services. On Chongming Island outside of Shanghai there are still a few families who carry  on this tradition, like the Zhu family.

properties.title: Retail Store
properties.description: Shopping for a bed cover Made in China. In 2010, the US imported almost 30 billion dollars of apparel from China, making it the third largest category of goods imported from China to the US, behind machinery and power equipment.

properties.title: TS Designs
properties.address: 2053 Willow Spring Ln, Burlington, NC 27215, USA
properties.description: A consumer in South Carolina doesn't have to look far to purchase an open supply chain t-shirt. In North Carolina, the company TS Designs makes and prints t-shirts using environmentally sustainable methods. With an open supply chain of 700 miles for some of its products, consumers can easily see the work and impact behind the production of their clothing.

properties.title: Cotton Ginning to Eastern Trading Company Cotton Merchants
Cameron Ginning to Savannah Cotton Warehouse
Savannah Cotton Warehouse to Port of Savannah
Port of Savannah to Yangshan Deep Water Port
Transport from Yangshan to Wai Gao Qiao Free Trade Zone
Transport from Wai Gao Qiao Warehouse to Changzhou, China
Eastdye Textile Company to Shen You Textile Company
Factory to Market (Food for the Workers)
Shanghai to Hangzhou Cotton Products Factory

properties.description: The Cotton Road documentary connects our consumption to the people, places, and labor that make the products we consume. Explore the labor, transportation and environmental impacts behind a typical supply chain for a cotton product.
properties.title: Cotton Road
